Wobblies timeline

Inspired and sourced from the graphic novel: Wobblies! A Graphic History of the Industrial Workers of the World, featuring a different comic artist for each subject/era. And colly.com, who's timeline I've always admired.

What struck me was the way that each artists paid tribute to whatever prominent figure they were drawing. Before returning the book to library i snapped photos as a way to help remember their stories

  • 1905

    The Industrial Workers of the World (IWW), the Wobblies, was formed in Chicago. They represent the working class With a focus direct action.

    At one time they had 100k members in the US and 10k+ worldwide. They aim to unite all workers, regardless of skill level or trade, into one big union to overthrow capitalism and establish a more just society.

  • 1905

    "Big" Bill Haywood is one of the founding members; his leadership played a crucial role in several successful strikes and campaigns, such as the 1905 and 1912 textile workers' strike in Lawrence, MA.

    "The mine owners did not find the gold, they did not mine the gold, they did not mill the gold, but by some weird alchemy, all the gold belonged to them."

  • 1909

    Elizabeth Gurley Flynn joins the IWW and becomes a prominent figure in the labor movement.

    "I am not a humanitarian, I am a hell-raiser."

  • 1911

    "T-Bone" Slim Brundage was an traveling worker who wrote songs and poems promoting the IWW message, eventually influencing Kerouak and Ginsburg.

    "The only good scab is a dead scab."

  • 1911

    Magon Brothers were Mexican anarchist leaders spread their message through their newspaper. Their work inspired many in Mexico and they became widely respected as champions of social justice and equality worldwide.

    "All the tyrannies of which the working class is victim are born of the government and capitalism. The government is the head of the monster; capitalism is its body."

  • 1912

    Joe Hill joins the IWW and writes many songs that become popular among labor unions, including "The Preacher and the Slave" and "There is Power in a Union."

    "A pamphlet, no matter how good, is never read more than once. But a song is learned by heart and repeated over and over."

  • 1913

    Mabel Dodge, a wealthy socialite, becomes involved in labor activism after attending an IWW meeting. She uses her influence to support the labor movement.

    "The economic freedom of women is necessary to free our civilization from the tyranny of the patriarchal family."

  • 1917

    Frank Little had a way of connecting with workers and inspiring them to take action, and his organizing efforts were successful in many cases, such as the copper mines in Montana.

    "Workers of the world, awaken! Break your chains, demand your rights. All the wealth you produce belongs to you, not to a minority of parasites."

  • 1920s

    Mother Jones is involved in the West Virginia Mine Wars and continues to advocate for workers' rights.

    "Pray for the dead and fight like hell for the living."

  • 1921

    Paul Robeson was an African American known for his powerful baritone voice and his ability to convey a deep sense of emotion through his singing. He was also an accomplished actor and athlete -- an All-American football player in college.

    "The artist must take sides. He must elect to fight for freedom or for slavery. I have made my choice."

  • 1926

    Emma Goldman, a prominent anarchist and labor activist, becomes involved with the IWW and gives speeches on behalf of the organization.

    "The most violent element in society is ignorance."

  • 1990

    Judi Bari, an environmental and labor activist, is injured when a bomb explodes in her car in Oakland, California. Despite being targeted for her activism, she is later falsely accused by the FBI of being responsible for the bombing.

    "The only way we can stop the destruction of the Earth and its people is to build alliances. And the only way to build alliances is to be honest and respectful with each other."
